title: AFP charge three men with displaying extremist Nazi symbols | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian Federal Police have charged three men during a week-long operation targeting Nazi symbols. This initiative led to the arrest of three men, including a 21-year-old Queensland man who allegedly possessed violent extremist material. title: Harnessing the people power of co-ops to stave off privatisation | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: A goldrush-era pub has been acquired by hundreds of Castlemaine locals who came together to buy it — without going to a bank.  The heritage building is known as the Hub and it houses small businesses and not-for-profits, a cafe and a community garden.The main concern from locals was that private buyers might swoop in and see the building through the lens of financial gain, adding to what some perceive as a "broken" local property market. Warwick Smith, an economist, helped hatch the plan to buy the double-titled property through the Castlemaine Community Investment Co-operative.    Co-operatives are member-owned organisations, operating for the benefit of those who sign up.  Members then own and control the enterprise, typically to operate an asset or run a business.  Those who buy into a co-op are direct owners, and profits or benefits go back to them. More communities nationally are turning to this economic model — buying everything from pubs to aged care centres — in what one advocate describes as a simmering national movement. #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here:  https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-12-08/castlemaine-cooperative-privatisation-economic-democracy/106103270  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: Are Wall Street titans' fears of a 2026 tech wreck justified? | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: The boom in artificial intelligence has driven market gains for another year, but it's also given rise to fears of a forming bubble. Several Wall Street titans have expressed concerns, including JP Morgan's Jamie Dimon, who recently said he was "worried" about a big correction. Since the introduction of AI assistant ChatGPT three years ago, the tech heavy NASDAQ has risen by more than 100 per cent. Co-founder of tech driven equities fund Minotaur Capital, Armina Rosenberg says she expects there's likely to be a 10-15 per cent market correction next year. However, she says valuations in the tech and AI sector now are stretched, but they're not as high as they were during the dot-com bubble of the 90s. She says the Magnificent 7 stocks have a much lower price-to-earnings ratio compared to the top seven stocks of 2000.  #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Aussie dollar at record high ahead of RBA interest rate decision | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian dollar has reach 66.4 US cents after the past few weeks of rallying amid market expectations of interest rate hikes next year.  Meanwhile, the US Federal Reserve is also meeting, and markets are expecting a rate cut, which has led the US share market to rally in 9 of the last 10 sessions.  The Australian market has declined, primarily due to losses in the banking and mining sectors, though Telstra and CSL posted gains. #abcbusiness  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Rajwinder Singh guilty of murdering Toyah Cordingley on Queensland beach | ABC NEWS
description: A former nurse, Rajwinder Singh, has been convicted of murdering Toyah Cordingley in 2018. Her body was found buried on a remote beach in Far North Queensland. Singh, 41, stabbed Ms Cordingley and cut her throat at Wangetti Beach. He then fled to India, where he spent four years in hiding. title: One of PNG's conjoined twins dies after surgical separation | ABC NEWS
description: A rare set of conjoined twins from Papua New Guinea have undergone surgery in Sydney. One of the twins, Tom, has died while his brother Sawong has survived. Sawong is in intensive care at Sydney Children's Hospital. description: Conflict at the Thailand-Cambodia border has reignited as both sides accuse each other of breaching a ceasefire agreement signed following the five-day war in July. Thailand's military has launched air strikes along the disputed border after at least one Thai soldier was killed in the skirmishes. title: Barnaby Joyce defects to One Nation as Coalition splinters | ABC NEWS
description: Former Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce has officially joined Pauline Hanson's One Nation party, ending weeks of speculation about his political future. Once a leader of the Nationals, Joyce will sit-out the term as a One Nation MP before running for the Senate at the next election. Joyce's defection comes amid a major shift in the Coalition as factions emerge from polarising policies. description: The Bulahdelah community is grieving not only the loss of homes, but also the life of a 59-year-old firefighter who was killed during a backburning exercise near the fire front. title: Government to scrap energy bill rebates from 2026 | ABC NEWS
description: Power bills are set to rise from January 2026 when the government scraps its $300 per year electricity rebate. The subsidy has been in place for 18 months, providing much-needed bill relief for households and many small businesses. Treasurer Jim Chalmers said it was a "hard" decision made in recognition of "pressure on the budget". It comes as the Coalition turned up the heat on Anika Wells over a series travel expenses billed to taxpayers. title: Pro-Beijing candidates dominate Hong Kong elections  | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Hong Kong has recorded a low turnout at their legislative council election, with fewer than 32% of voters casting their ballots. The elections have been overshadowed by the deadly apartment complex fire that has killed at least 156 people and left residents angry and traumatised. Human Rights Watch Asia Director Elaine Pearson spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about voter attitudes in Hong Kong. title: 'Crying for joy': Syria marks one year since fall of Assad | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Celebrations are underway in Syria's capital to celebrate a year since the fall of the Assad regime. In December last year, dictator Bashar Al-Assad was toppled by Islamist rebels, bringing an end to nearly 14 years of civil war, but families across Syria are still trying to rebuild. Human rights advocate and director for detainee affairs at the Syrian Emergency Task Force Omar Alshogre spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about the feeling among Syrians as they mark the occasion. title: Flood disaster cripples isolated areas in Indonesia | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Calls are growing for Indonesia's government to declare a national emergency in the wake of flooding and landslides that have left almost 1,000 people dead. As Rebecca Johnston reports, people living in isolated areas were some of the hardest hit, and are now facing the spread of disease and a lack of access to medical care. title: Thailand launches air strikes amid new border clashes with Cambodia | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Fighting has broken out once again on the Thai-Cambodian border, with both sides accusing each other of breaching a ceasefire agreement signed after the five-day war in July. Thailand launched air strikes after a Thai soldier was killed and four wounded in fresh clashes in the easternmost province of Ubon Ratchathani, the Thai military said. The Cambodian side said Thailand had launched dawn attacks and that Cambodian troops had not retaliated. The ABC's Asia Editor Karishma Vyas spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about the latest on the ground. title: Toyah's Murder: The Verdict
description: The 12 people who have been deciding whether Rajwinder Singh is guilty or not guilty of the 2018 murder of Toyah Cordingley have returned their verdict.   In this episode, ABC Cairns reporter, Chris Testa takes you into the courtroom as the jury reads their decision and talks to Stephen Stockwell about the reactions in the courtroom. He also reveals a secret we had to keep while the trial was in progress.   If you have any questions you'd like Chris and Stocky to answer in future episodes, please email thecaseof@abc.net.au (mailto:thecaseof@abc.net.au) .   The Case Of is the follow-up to the hit podcast Mushroom Case Daily, and all episodes of that show will remain available in the back catalogue of The Case Of.
